title: 112_s1445
content: The Act is titled the "Raechel and Jacqueline Houck Safe Rental Car Act of 2011" and includes definitions for various terms. The "Raechel and Jacqueline Houck Safe Rental Car Act of 2011" defines a "covered vehicle" as a motor vehicle rated at 26,000 pounds gross vehicle weight or less, rented or leased without a driver, and part of a fleet of 5 or more vehicles used for rental or lease purposes. It also defines terms like "defect", "motor vehicle", "motor vehicle safety", and "motor vehicle safety standard". The terms "defect", "motor vehicle", "motor vehicle safety", and "motor vehicle safety standard" are defined in section 30102 of title 49, United States Code. The term "person" is defined in section 1 of title 1, United States Code. A "rental company" is a person engaged in renting or leasing covered vehicles for rental or lease purposes. A rental company is defined as a person engaged in the business of renting or leasing covered vehicles with a motor vehicle fleet of 5 or more covered vehicles. PROHIBITION ON RENTAL, LEASE, AND SALE OF DEFECTIVE CARS AND TRUCKS. Prohibition on rental, lease, or sale of covered vehicles with safety defects or non-compliance. The manufacturer must notify owners, purchasers, and dealers if a covered vehicle has a safety defect or does not comply with safety standards before rental, lease, or sale. An exception applies if the Secretary orders a notification and enforcement is set aside in a civil action. The manufacturer must notify owners, purchasers, and dealers of safety defects in covered vehicles before rental, lease, or sale. An exception applies if the Secretary orders a notification and enforcement is set aside in a civil action. Rental companies are considered to have received a notification 5 business days after it was mailed. During a rental or lease period, if a rental company receives a notification that a covered vehicle has a safety defect, they must immediately contact the renter or lessee and any authorized driver with immediate contact information. During a rental or lease period, if a rental company receives a notification that a vehicle has a safety defect, they must contact the renter and offer a comparable alternative vehicle at no extra cost until the issue is resolved. The rental company must provide a comparable alternative vehicle at no extra cost to the renter in case of a safety defect, until the issue is resolved. This section will be effective 60 days after the enactment of the Act. The Federal Trade Commission will enforce the provisions outlined in the Act, effective 60 days after enactment. Violation of section 3 of this Act will be treated as a violation of a rule under the Federal Trade Commission Act regarding unfair or deceptive acts. The Federal Trade Commission will enforce this Act with the same powers and duties as under the Federal Trade Commission Act. Penalties will apply to those who violate this Act or its regulations. Any person who violates this Act or its regulations will be subject to penalties and entitled to privileges under the Federal Trade Commission Act. The Commission's authority under other laws is not limited by this section. SEC. 5. ENFORCEMENT BY STATES. The attorney general of a State can bring an action in a US district court for violations of the Act to obtain injunctive relief. The Federal Trade Commission must be notified in certain cases. Section 1391 of title 28, United States Code allows the attorney general of a State to seek injunctive relief for violations of the Act. The Federal Trade Commission must be notified before initiating a civil action. The attorney general of a State can seek injunctive relief for violations of the Act, with notice to the Federal Trade Commission before initiating a civil action. The notice must include a copy of the complaint to be filed. If providing notice is not feasible, the State must notify immediately upon instituting a civil action. The State must provide immediate notice upon instituting a civil action under the Act. The Federal Trade Commission can intervene in the action, be heard on all matters, and file petitions for appeal. Nothing in this section shall be construed to limit these provisions. The attorney general of a State can intervene in civil actions, file petitions for appeal, and exercise powers conferred by state laws. This section does not limit the attorney general's authority at the state or federal level. The attorney general of a State, or other authorized State officer, can take legal action based on state laws. No separate suit can be filed under this section if the same violation is already being addressed by the Federal Trade Commission or the United States. SEC. 6. CONSTRUCTION. This Act does not prevent individuals from seeking remedies under Federal or State law. SEC. 7. NATIONAL HIGHWAY TRAFFIC SAFETY ADMINISTRATION REPORT ON SALES OF MOTOR VEHICLES TO RENTAL COMPANIES WITHOUT STANDARD SAFETY FEATURES. The Administrator of the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration must submit a report to Congress within 180 days on rental companies buying motor vehicles without standard safety features typically included for consumers. The Administrator of the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration must report to Congress on rental companies purchasing motor vehicles without standard safety features, including implications on consumer safety and recommendations for regulatory actions. SEC. 8. National Highway Traffic Safety Administration report on sales of motor vehicles by rental companies with safety defects before recalls. The Administrator of the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration must submit a report to Congress within 180 days of the Act's enactment on sales of covered vehicles by rental companies that are aware of safety defects or non-compliance with safety standards. The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration must report to Congress within 180 days on rental companies selling vehicles with safety defects or non-compliance with safety standards. Rental companies must be aware of these issues and take action promptly. The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration must report to Congress within 180 days on rental companies selling vehicles with safety defects or non-compliance with safety standards. Rental companies must take action promptly upon notification of defects related to motor vehicles. The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration must report to Congress within 180 days on rental companies selling vehicles with safety defects or non-compliance with safety standards. The report should include a description and analysis of the frequency of sales of affected vehicles and a discussion of the effects on consumers. The Administrator must provide a follow-up report to Congress within 1 year of the initial report, including recommendations on legislative and administrative actions to address sales of vehicles with safety defects and their impact on consumers. The Administrator must submit a follow-up report to Congress within 1 year of the initial report, detailing the sales of covered vehicles and their effects. The follow-up report to Congress must include a description, analysis, discussion, and recommendations for the period specified, along with an identification and analysis of differences in findings between reports. The follow-up report to Congress must include an analysis of differences in findings between reports and a discussion of the effects of the Act on vehicle sales.
